ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: Minimal
2 hours total
I spent about 3 hours total to complete the necessary training.
Just a few hours on the HIPAA courses
1 seminar - 3 hours.
This session took twice as long as it should have... A more concise discussion of the material would have served to greatly improve the experience.
I spent no more than 2 hours to complete the necessary requirements for this course.
4-5 hours on the certificates after the one-time course
1 hour
The course takes 2 hours for one day, period.
10 hours once
I spent about 3 hours outside of the seminar on work.
Not many at all
3-4 hours preparation for a one time course
3-4 hours in total
Not applicable. A one-time course.
One time seminar... work took about 45 minutes to complete.
none
0 hours per week
2 hours.
less than 1
Less than 1
1 hour
none
Probably 1.5 to do the HIPAA certifications
0 hours, was a one-time course.
3 hours

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: The class appeared to be somehow irrelevant to students in policy and management track.
IRRELEVANT
Ethics as an area of study is quite engaging. Unfortunately, this seminar was quite onerous to sit through.
NA
good

I like the presented ethical conundrum, but found the course to be a little stretched out. I think that It could have been done as an online program. It should have at least provided some sort of dinner or snack given its timing
good course

I think this course was a good idea conceptually, but it was poorly executed. Logistically, it was held on an evening with lots of commitments and upcoming assignments and exams. It was also held over dinner hours, but there was not any food or any break to go get food.I am generally interested in research ethics and would actually enjoy a course on the subject, but this quick overview was not particularly focused. I liked the discussion, but was disappointed in other students' refusal to participate. I left the seminar without gaining anything, which was a disappointment.The problem with these one-time seminars is that they become disjointed from the rest of the YSPH experience. They become a box to check, instead of a chance to integrate some new material and experiences into our career preparation. This will be difficult to address without some type of ongoing seminar that holds students accountable for preparation and participation. Similar to the professional development seminar, these "core skills" don't develop from a one-time workshop. It takes time to develop and improve these skills.One suggestion that would be easier to implement is to have discussions take place in separate break-out sessions with a small number of students and a moderator in each group. Discussions with 100+ hungry, tired, stressed grad students rarely work well, but they are important conversations to have.I also was disappointed that the famous Tuskegee experiment (and other case studies) were barely mentioned. While I can appreciate an objective component to establish philosophical frameworks, how could we take an ethics seminar and NOT talk about Tuskegee?!

Dr. Jennings is very knowledgeable and gave a good background of public health ethics in the limited time that we had. I don't think the discussions were effective in such a large group. Perhaps have smaller discussion groups, even if there aren't enough instructors/TA's to moderate the small discussions.

For anyone who has every done research or human subjects work this was not very helpful. Hearing the theory behind ethics is interesting but having already had to sit through a HIC introductory lecture I got nothing new.Rather than a seminar I think people should have to simply complete the HIPAA trainings as they quiz you on your understanding of research ethics or it should be a only based on break out sessions.
Strength: very important topic
Worthwhile and thoughtful discussion, but lecture was a bit laborious and slow. Worth cutting down to maybe half its current weight.
This course is entirely unnecessary as we could have received all of the material online.
This module was quite frankly a waste of time. I did not walk out of the seminar having learned anything new and it was not engaging in the slightest.
I didn't see this course was necessary because we learned from the online courses for the certificates after all.
It was a fine subject matter and an interesting lecture, but please don't have a 5-7 pm lecture with no food! It's fine to not provide food, but don't have it during primary dinner time.
below average. Had good potential.

This class was a joke and it shouldn't have been. It was incredibly boring and I learned nothing. Ethics is a very very important issue and I feel as though the way it was presented made people take it less seriously.
The topic is pretty self-explanatory

I think this course would of been better suited as an online course that we could take on our own time. This course was taught at a very inconvenient time during the semester, and should have taken place earlier.

This was the biggest waste of time of my entire life. Firstly, there was no food even though the course was at dinner time and it went 30 minutes late. Second, the discussion activity was so poorly designed that the complexities of the situation could not be actually discussed. I'm telling you, it is leadership 101. If you want people to be happy and pay attention at something that they don't want to be at anyways, give them food. This class was so miserable.
Good idea in theory, bad in practice.

Having a seminar on ethics is important. I would say that done with all of the students in the class, however, make it difficult to be as meaningful as it should be. One, because students are packed like sardines in an uncomfortable room and two, because non-agressive people are less likely to speak up in such a big crowd.I think the course could be improved without Dr. Jennings as the instructor.
The seminar provided a solid foundation for research ethics. I have studied ethics in the past, so this course was very redundant for me.
Kind of boring... But it was only 2 hours so it was no big deal.
Excellent and very relevant course which should be offered as an elective.

This class felt redundant. I think covering this topics as part of our general coursework would have been far more effective. The example discussion was stupid. In general, I'm not sure I really got much out of it, but on the whole I guess I'd rather have it be shorter than longer. Also, feeding us that late at night when we were there for so long would have been an excellent idea. It would have made me far more inclined to pay attention.They also could have started with an interactive example or a historical example to walk us through as they explained the concepts rather than a very dry initial presentation.
It was adequate. I think the HIIPA and IRB modules were the only useful part.
interesting
Great seminar.
Not very practical in my opinion. The one-session course took material that could have been taught in a year and condensed it down to 3 hours.
Great. Short is good.
Not sure if I learned much from this course.

I think that ethics is really interesting, and I see the importance of the topic. I think that it is incredibly difficult to engage people who do not feel the same way when the class is taught to over 100 people in an auditorium. I think it would be better to have concentration-specific ethics courses.
Do not see the future use or importance of this to my future career path.
Strength- nothingWeakness- Most students already took modules on this topic. The seminar felt redundant..just another check in a box.
Perhaps it was because I had a midterm the day after, but I did not learn anything and was not sure why this seminar was required
The first hour was very theoretical, which could have been cut down. Breakout sessions would help encourage greater student participation.

The seminar was okay. I am happy it was only a one time thing. I wish they had sent out a reminder email to complete the modules. This seminar was during a very busy time for first years. Many of us were in the middle of internship searches and had interviews. It would have been nice to have received a reminder email about the required modules to complete.
The timing of the seminar was inconvenient, which really detracted from the actual material.
Very poorly structured seminar. Disappointing.

Strengths: the one-time structure of the seminar made the course more manageable.Weaknesses: the large section without any group break off time or exercises led to poor student interaction and practice of the applicability of ethics concepts.
Boring. did not need to be a class--better if it was online.
Not truly an effective way of teaching research ethics
Great discussion.
Subject matter was very dry and hypothetical. Taking the online courses alone should have sufficed.
Course did not relate to our summer internship at all. It was too theoretical and failed to address real-world ethical concerns we may encounter for those of us going abroad.
very boring lecture - not relevantinteractive group portion was fun
thought-provoking
I thought that the course did not offer much to the program. It was not very engaging to the students overall.

A nice overview, but there were a lot of heavy topics to cover in a very short amount of time. The large group format made discussion more difficult, but the speaker handled that well. The scenarios were interesting.

The content and instructor were good, however nobody takes this serious. Hardly anyone pays attention and people are preoccupied doing their schoolwork, instead of listening.Improvement: I wish this pointless seminar wasn't require, but I'm sure that won't change. Can we at least get fed. We were starving on a Thursday night. The seminar runs from 5-7pm, we should at least have been given snacks.

It was given near midterms and at such a bad time of year. Also, there was no food? That seems kind of tacky.Have it at the beginning of the year. Have break out groups. Engage students more. Don't let us all play on our laptops the whole class. It seemed rude to the professor.
Waste of time
It did the job of talking about ethics. I think it would have been better if we had discussion groups though.
I think it would have been sufficient for us to just do the online trainings and certifications.
a little be long

It's a waste of time and tuition dollars. I've been a physian for 20 years. I know what informed consent is.You should be allowed to waive out of this class, as is the case for professional skills in Fall semester.
I have no idea how this course is about ethics in research. The lecture focused on history and ethic terms. Absolutely nothing was useful about this lecture
The course was theory based and failed to really connect back to public health. Was overall a waste of a Thursday evening.
Not pertinent to everyone

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Bruce Jennings  I believe the instructor failed to engage the audience. The slides were excruciatingly wordy and the instructor had a tendency to regurgitate the material verbatim opposed to synthesizing it in a captivating way.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  NA
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  good
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Very likeable and easy to listen to, although some of the content was drawn out.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  funny professor but only met him for a short period of time

Instructor: Bruce Jennings  I was disappointed in his talk because I think he is an interesting lecturer, but the lecture seemed unfocused. There were also pacing issues; the lecture moved too slowly.I'm also not sure why this class had a TA for a short discussion when Bruce could have led it just as easily...
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Good
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  He seemed very nice but there was no teacher-student interactions.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Very kind and eloquent.

Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Nice man, thoughtful and amusing presentation. But, again, suffered from a lack of direction or forward energy, and as a result the session lagged without addressing all of the necessary material.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Dr. Jennings is very nice but incredibly dry during his lectures. It seems unnecessary for him to have to talk at us for 3 hours.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  The discussion topic during the one-time course was interesting.

Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Dr, Jennings is clearly very enthusiastic about this topic and gave an interesting and informative lecture on the importance of ethics in research and an overview of the structure of modern bioethics
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Fair. Not a good format for his style of teaching.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  This session was poorly designed and poorly run. In addition, he ran 20 minutes over time, which in my opinion is disrespectful of people's time.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Good discussion
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  So unbelievably boring. He did not capture my attention in any way.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Rambling.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  The professor was rather dry, and too wordy.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  The instructor was clear and he interacted with us which was good.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Very nice
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Very knowledgeable.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  .
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  informative
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Good
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Monotonous.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Organized

Instructor: Bruce Jennings  I thought that Bruce Jennings was clearly knowledgeable, but his teaching style was not really suited for a one time course. I think people would have been more receptive to long slides and multiple lessons in a course that spanned more than 1 night.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Loves the topics/passionate about the material
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Strength- He was patient and enthusiastic about the topic.Weakness- He was painfully slow at explaining everything and had poor time management skills.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Could improve on lecturing skills and make the seminar more interactive.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Not very exciting.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Monotonous and dry.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Nice but very dry
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Instructor was knowledgable however did not engage the class except for one very basic exercise that was not fruitful.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  material was difficult to understand - too high level

Instructor: Bruce Jennings  great speaker, the slides were a bit overwhelming at times, went over time and had to rush towards the end.. everything said was interesting, so I wish we didn't have to rush
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Good speaker, solid understanding of his audience.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  He did the best he could with the short time period and the disinterest of the crowd. I feel bad that he is forced to do this.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  He seems really great, just unfortunate that he was in a room full of students who were studying for the Epi exam the next day.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Nice guy
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Nice guy.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Good speaker.
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  can not judge him with just a 2 and a half hour's class
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  Boring presentation
Instructor: Bruce Jennings  He had a lot to say and could definitely teach an excellent course on this subject. The format was too rushed for his style.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: No.
good
I would recommend it as I found it helpful and takes only a little time. Although I think that I learned just as much from my required online trainings as I did during the actual course.
yes
This is a disappointing required seminar. You will lose about 5-6 hours of your life for it. Also, bring a snack.
Good, very brief, overview
Kind of unhelpful.
This course was required and important.

There was nothing in this course that I have not learned numerous times in other capacities. If it was not required, I would not recommend it to anyone who has ever done research, IRB training, or HIPAA certification before.
Necessary and harmless, but might interfere with your schedule.
No, I would not recommend this course to any students as it was entirely a waste of time and could have been done more efficiently in the form of an online module.

People from the Policy department might be interested in this course.However, for people from CDE or EMD who are doing research themselves might already know about the ethics issues and may seem to be redundant.
Interesting lecture, important topic.
Below average due to the way it was formatted.

It was required. I can't stress enough that YSPH needs to re-do this course so that this VERY IMPORTANT aspect of public health is taken seriously and an honest discussion about the grey areas of ethics could be fleshed out more seriously. A recommendation would be to have this run by Steven Lantham at the Yale Center for Bioethics. Just a thought.
Required seminar but pretty self-explanatory to begin with
This class is required so you have to take it but it is the biggest waste of time and you will learn nothing from it.
Could have been done better. Bioethics can be incredibly interesting, but this was a waste.
It is a one night seminar that covers the basics of ethics and its place in research.
Just get it done
Excellent course. Relevant topicc.
I would recommend this course to a fellow student. It is informative and not time-consuming.
The course is mandatory. But I would not recommend it to another student. The material can be learned elsewhere.
Good readings
This course can be done over online tutorial and quiz.

As the course stands, I would say that it is a one-night course that covers ethical theory and decision making for public health. It is a very interesting topic, but I probably would not recommend it to another student (although it is not optional).
Requirement to graduate.

I would not recommend this course to a student because I gained nothing from it. I already knew the material. Why did we have to listen to an entire lecture from him while doing additional modules on the subject material? This course was unnecessary.
It's a requirement, but I suppose if you do not have any understanding of ethical issues in research then it might be a good seminar to take.
Required course for all students
Required seminar on research ethics.
It was a required seminar. It may have been more engaging at a better time.
Don't recommend unless an absolute requirement.

The seminar on research ethics is a one time course that briefly touches on some of the important and complex issues of bioethics, patient privacy, among others. The readings and short assignment provided are meant to expose non-research based students and refresh the knowledge of those with prior experience on research.
It's mandatory. If it wasn't I would not recommend it.
consists of one long lecture and a few online certifications. Not very time consuming or difficult.
Not the best course.
Should only be done with online modules.
I wouldn't recommend this to another student although it is required. If the course could be more relatable to students working in underserved communities then it would be helpful.
required
interesting course, but too much material for one class
Good first look at ethical issues in public health, take a full fledged course if you really want to get a good understanding of the material covered.

A pointless formality. You are forced to sit through this and you aren't even fed. It's hard to focus when you are starving and/or have other assignments or exams to study for. I remember this seminarwas the day before the epi exam, something which made us all angry.
My guess is you have to take it.
The least we could've had was dinner since we were there so late
Obvious material so it certainly won't take much brain power.

Well organized, but lecture was a little boring. However, I understand such a topic is hard to be made less boring. Students need to be more attentive though, I thought a lot of students who fell asleep were very disrespective. Many thanks to the people who organized this seminar, especially to the speaker, Bruce Jennings.
it's required

Good intentions but too much material to be taught in a two hour frame. More organized PPTs would be helpful. Would be more useful and applicable if students were break into their respective departments and have group discussions instead.
This is a required course. I don't know why. I didn't learn anything.
Not worth the time in the current format
It is required, but provides a decent overview into ethics and ethical concerns.
Only to those interested and actively engaged in research
